data.text:
Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Please, wonât you join me in welcoming Mr Chuck D.

[Applause]

Yesterday, all these participants came in on their first day and introduced themselves, talked a little bit about their personal journey to get here. I wondered if you might share your journey to get to music, because it really wasnât part of the game plan originally, right?

Chuck D

No. Number one, my personal journey to get here yesterday was kind of f---ed up by London Heathrow and then Iberia Airlines, they just took all damn day and they lost my bag. So I couldnât make you a really righteous CD, I just pulled something off what I call a Vamp player, which Iâll show you later. My personal musical journey came by accident because I grew up as a big sports fan. In New York, where I was born, in Queens, I was a big fan of baseball, which is the New York Mets, and basketball, which is the New York Knicks, and American football, which is the New York Jets. And around the time, I was eight or nine, they all won their championships, so that threw me further into fanaticism. I just wanted to be a sports announcer, listening to sports talk shows.

Music was always in my household. My mother was into Motown, Stax, Atlantic in the â60s, my father played jazz and some James Brown. I listened to music quite casually, but then in the 1970s I listened to a lot of AM radio â big AM radio fan. WABC was the radio station in the New York metropolitan area. It played top 40, pop radio, but what I thought was exciting were the DJs, the jocks, and the way they used to come on, [affects voice] âWABC, Dan Ingram.â I just loved the voices, and I wanted to become a sports announcer. And there was one guy who bridged the gap, George Michael.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

The Sports Machine, not the George Michael you may all know from âCareless Whisper.â

Chuck D

Not that George Michael. He was a DJ on WABC, so when he flipped over into sports, I thought that was a cool thing. The music bug bit me around â76/â77. I wanted to play ball all the time and I went to this place called Higher Ground, named after the Stevie Wonder record. Half of the place was basketball, half was music with this thing they called a âDJ.â Now, we always thought a DJ meant a discotheque guy, and they would wear silk shirts and be behind this gigantic foundation platform. So, we would walk a mile to this place in the wintertime to try to get our ball on. But they only had two rims, and everybody wanted to be at this place that was open to the kids, so youâre looking at two basketball rims with 100 brothers waiting to play. So, who got next? This shitâs gonna take forever. But as youâre sitting there, knowing damn well youâre not going to play, on the other side of the gym was this DJ, wearing a silk shirt as all of us just had these tank tops or whatever. Before, music and sports were totally different things. So, we were over on one side, trying to look hard, just nodding our heads.

This is when disco was just coming in from the âover funkâ period â when funk got played out because everybody was trying to do it. Once David Bowie did âFameâ, it was like, âOK, Iâm tired of this shit.â Disco came in, and it started off quite funky, because you had The OâJays and âI Love Musicâ, a lot of the Gamble & Huff sort of stuff, strings and orchestral arrangements and The Stylistics and Thom Bell. Theyâd upped the tempo and changed the beat, and thatâs how disco came in, and it was very cool in the beginning, around â75/â77.

So, the DJ was playing this record from the group War, whoâd suddenly upped their tempo. A lot of the funk groups upped their tempos: Mandrill, War, better-known groups like Kool & the Gang, when they did âLadies Nightâ two years later. Weâre watching this DJ as weâre waiting to play some ball and the DJ is playing âGalaxyâ by War. So Iâm sitting there and I liked how the song sounded on the radio, it would start out on WWRL â which was a soul station in New York with incredible DJs, Hank Spann and Enoch Hawthorne Gregory, Gerry Bledsoe â and they had the best voices in the world. [Affects voice] âWelcome to WWRL, the Super 16 (because it was 1600 on the AM dial), hereâs a song by War, âGalaxy.ââ And it would come in [does the beat and sings], you can Google it, Limewire it, in case you think Iâm tripping.

This DJ played the same record, but the words never came in. He was like, [does âGalaxyâ beat over and over], and I couldnât understand why the words couldnât come in. He extended it for about 10 to 12 minutes. This shows you how people didnât understand anything about DJing, and Iâm from New York, because automatically people think cats from New York are just, âYeah, yeah. It always was like thatâ¦â No, weâre country as a motherf---er, man, especially in Long Island, which is only 15 minutes out. I was like, âHow is he making the record go like that?â You couldnât really see two turntables, you had no idea what he was doing behind the DJ stand, he was just moving like side to that side, he had a light in his face. I said, âThat record must be about this big [holds arms out]. How can it be that it still hasnât stopped!â That was my first introduction to the technical aspect of DJing, I totally did not understand how one record could be extended into another. That bit me.

Later on, tapes were going out and people were making pause tapes off the radio stations. One tape that got me was DJ Hollywoodâs son, DJ Smalls. The Jacksons... how many of you know Michael Jackson? How many of you know the Jacksons were produced by Gamble & Huff in â75/â77? How many of you know Gamble & Huff? OKâ¦ Gamble & Huff were Philadelphia International, which was signed by CBS Records, which really they were distributed by them. They were the in-house producers, and they were hot producers, so they were producing everyone in the CBS soul tank. They had just picked up the Jackson 5 from Motown in 1975, but they couldnât use the â5â because Berry Gordy had sued CBS for use of the name. So, the Jacksons without Jermaine were just called the Jacksons. And on the album Goinâ Places, which had all the Jacksons moving, going forward, Michael included â because Michel Jacksonâs a bad-ass motherf--er, I donât care what anybody says â they had this song called âMusicâs Taking Over,â which starts off with this groove [sings], and this is the break part [does the beat]. I heard it on the tape, and once again the record was really short intro then boom into the record, but this groove was going on forever. And I was hearing Michael Jacksonâs voice âLetâs, letâs, letâs, letâs.â And I was like, âWhy is Michael doing that shit?â Then âLetâs dance, letâs dance, letâs dance.â So, I went to the store to buy the 45, and it started off, went into the song and faded out, because it was a 45. I was like, âThis ainât the shit I heard.â Thatâs what really bit me.

To make a long story short, the technical aspect of what DJs were bringing to the music is what started hip hop; the curiosity of taking something that was given to you as a recording and flipping it, whether it be at a party or a tape. And cassette tapes were new then, they were developed in â64, but they hit the hood when people could afford to make pause tapes with cheap players. Thatâs why itâs no secret that the holy trinity of hip-hop are Kool Herc, Afrika Bambaataa, the Master Of Records, and Grandmaster Flash. Thatâs the holy trinity, it starts right there because their influence with the recordings, taking them and flipping them in their three different circles, went into other areas â and youâve got to talk about Pete DJ Jones, guys like Maboya, and the big soundsystem DJs who came with the Jamaican aesthetic of two turntables and really manipulating disco/soul records. A lot of people didnât dig into funk and soul at first, but as disco went forward with more computerized shit, people went back and the guys from the streets started to dig back even more, finding things like James Brown âSex Machine,â and all those obscure records, like âApacheâ and âSeven Minutes Of Funk.â

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

I guess, at that point you were on Long Island.

Chuck D

Yeah, you take the bus to Jamaica and the E and the F train to the city. The thing about it is, everyone from the city had moved to Long Island, so Nassau County and Suffolk County are the only places in New York where you had people from everywhere in the city. Before that, people in Brooklyn had no reason to go the Bronx, absolutely no reason. You ask a person from the Bronx if they want to Brooklyn, theyâd say, âFor what?â Harlem in Manhattan was the center point, so a guy from Brooklyn would go to Manhattan and that would be the end of that, or they would stay in the planet of Brooklyn. Same thing with the Bronx, theyâd stay in the Bronx or they would come to Manhattan. You wouldnât find a person from the Bronx coming to Queens. People in Queens would venture into Manhattan and possibly the Bronx. So this migration in the â70s was very important for figuring out the gigs and the DJ, the music, all thatâs intertwined. RL was the soul station, but they canât front and say WABC wasnât an influence. You ask guys like Biz Markie and Bambaataa, and theyâll tell you: âHell yeah,â thatâs where their exposure to people like Steely Dan, Aerosmith and all that came from.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

When did you get exposed to things like the Cold Crush tapes â were those passed around at school by kids from the Bronx?

Chuck D

No, because when I graduated from high school it was â78 so those tapes werenât running around like that. They were more like â78, â79, â80. I was in college and in some other things. When you got into college you quickly severed yourself from all high school activity. When people talk about the parks, âYeah, I was in the parks!â Yeah, because you couldnât get in the clubs. The whole key was to get in the clubs, and the DJs excelling in the clubs were Eddie Cheeba and DJ Hollywood â they just totally dominated the club scene. Iâm 18 years old, and Iâll make no secret about it, Iâm trying to get into a club thatâs 18 and over so I can get with a girl, I ainât trying to get into no high-school shit. Iâm trying to get into club, college, and whip out as much ID as I can and these are the DJs that were dominating up in there. You had to dress up, which I didnât like to do, and the parks jumped off in the summertime, where you could be casual because you were outside. You canât be outside in January. So, before my exposure was before Cold Crush, it was to the DJs who were making tapes. The first street DJs to penetrate to me â other than me just following Hank Shocklee and Spectrum in â76-77, because they would bring Long Island and Queens with Infinity Machine and King Charles â they had a big terrain and I would follow them.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, these were the mobile soundsystems in Long Island doing big parties?

Chuck D

Not only were they mobile but you had to be mobile to catch them. The thing thatâs different from the Bronx or Brooklyn, is that people waited for things to come to them. In Long Island you had to go and check it, you got in your car and you went to the Bronx and Brooklyn and Queens, you drove there because you wanted to find the jump-off. That was key, and these are some of the things that are underwritten in the formation, because you talk about the New York metropolitan area... People are surprised that the first rap record â and weâre not going to talk about âKing Timâ and The Fatback Band, who had a recording contract knocking out things for Spring [Records], which I thought was incredible â but people were surprised that the first rap record came from guys from Jersey. You must understand the physical logistics of Inglewood, New Jersey â itâs right across the bridge, everybodyâs got the same radio station. So before tapes, the radio was dominant, the clubs were dominant, but also the parks and the streets were dominant. So the first street cats, who really cut across and ventured out and who I was impressed by, were Grandmaster Flash and Melle Mel; those guys blew me away. That was in 1979.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

When did you first encounter them?

Chuck D

Live in â79, because they were able to bleed into what was happening at the club level, and also at the college level.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Because they had records out at that point?

Chuck D

No, this was before that. Thereâs nothing in hip-hop â and Iâve been in front of stadiums of 75,000 people â I canât even explain the atmosphere in hip-hop and rap music before the first record. From January â78 to October â79, when the first rap record came out, I canât even explain to you the intensity of rap music and hip-hop. It was heading to a place where nobody expected it to go, no one knew where it would go. If youâd told me in 1979 that there would be a rap record, I wouldâve said it was inconceivable, it was impossible, because it was a whole party atmosphere type of thing. So, when Eddie Cheeba was going around in 1979 â I remember it clearly like it was yesterday â âIâve got this new record, Iâm going to break it for you.â And the place was packed and the name of the song was âGood Timesâ by Chic. People were used to dancing faster because Chic had brought you âDance, Dance, Danceâ and then later âLe Freak.â They considered that a slowing of the pace in â78, but when they did âGood Timesâ it was waaaay down. I found it hard to dance to. âWhat the f---, man! Gotta dance slow to this shit.â But really, that was New Yorkâs return to funk, which it escaped from around â73/â74.

That was the turning point because cats could rap on that speed and cut to that speed. I remember very clearly in the summer of 1979, they would have cats coming together, cutting up âGood Timesâ with their sneakers. 1979, New York City was rap-f---ing-crazy. They used to say, âGet that B-boy shit out of here!â But it was rap crazy. But this was before the records, and everybody had a feeling something was going to happen, but nobody knew exactly what. Eddie Cheeba would go around saying, âLook out, yâallâ â he broke the records, but he didnât make them â âIâm gonna put rap on a record soonâ âWhat the f--- are you talking about, how are you going to put rap on a record?â When âKing Tim IIIâ came out in July â79 , the Fatback Band had already been putting out some hot funky, disco-tinged joints. They were from Brooklyn, they would make songs people would dance to, so when they had King Tim III on it, it was âWhoa!â It sparked something, it was the click in the lightbulb. Then âRapperâs Delightâ came out in October, that was the dam that burst, it was âGood Times,â it was the âFirecrackerâ break by Mass Production. It was the two hottest songs on one record with street rap on it, and that was the beginning of the dam breaking and people were like, âWhoa, that shitâs a rap record.â Immediately, it went into the era of the record and the tapes became less of a force â big, but less of a force. It was about that record.

When âRapperâs Delightâ came out it was 15 minutes long. A lot of you might think that was a long-ass record, but the irony is, when it came out, it wasnât how long it was, but how short it was. Because to me and others, rap was a three-hour thing, and they got it down to 15 minutes. This is whatâs not really talked about because this is old headâs shit, but Iâm giving it to you straight from the horseâs mouth, because I always looked at black music, rap music, urban music as a science, as well as something to just enjoy, because I was a sports fan. And anyone who knows about sports knows you canât be a dumb motherf---er talking about sports. How many of you here like sports? See, thatâs why youâre music people. You go in a sports circle and donât know what the f--- youâre talking about, theyâll tell you to get the f--- out of here. I like people to think in music terms the same way as people talk about sports.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, when rap records came out, thatâs when you thought you had something to devote your life to. But it wasnât the music, right?

Chuck D

No, I was going to college and I got kicked out in my freshman year, I worked at a job, then I went to some other classes. I got into college as a graphic design phenom. I turned down a scholarship for architecture at New York Tech. I was really goodâ¦ as a matter of fact, I thought I was too good, but I had no direction. âOK, youâre good but what the hell are you gonna do?â So, when rap records came out, everything just kind of clicked for me. âWow, rap records â that means covers, that means graphics. I could use my graphics to work in an art department at a record company as records get bigger.â So, that made me go back to school and finish, because I wanted to work in the art department of a record company, doing covers and stuff. That pushed me through school. I loved the fact you could apply your art to the music.

Now, I wasnât a big graffiti fan. I would be going into work looking at the graffiti thinking half of it is wack, in fact, 90% of the graffiti I saw back in the day on the subway was just terrible to me. I was about getting really graphics to the point. I was a critic and thought I could do better. Just because youâve got a marker and a spray can, doesnât mean youâre right to be marking up shit. âThis dude shouldâve left his marker in his pocket instead of marking up this train, because this shit is wack.â But there were 10% of cats out there that were brilliant, I just thought there shouldâve been some kind of zone for them.

So, I just saw the graphic/music connection, and thatâs why I went through college. At college there was a radio station, WBAU, which I went on because I was a big rap fan. I got on the microphone because I thought back in the day 80% of all MCs were terrible and they would be on top of a DJ who was terrible. Youâd be trying to get your dance on with a girl. youâd get the courage to ask the girl to dance, and then all of a sudden, sheâd stop and look at the DJ and say, âI donât think I wanna dance no more,â so youâre mad at the DJ too, because heâs terrible and the MC is terrible. Iâm like, âMan, youâre f---ing my game up.â So, then I started to get on the mic to rhyme to sit the wack MCs down. If youâre in a long line and you let the first three MCs go and âLove Is The Messageâ comes on, all of a sudden, just because someoneâs from the Bronx they get on the mic too, âYeah, I know what this is.â Terrible. Then it was my turn, and the line behind me would disappear, because they would be like. âWell, I canât do that shit.â That was my main reason for getting on the microphone â to sit the wack MCs down so I could enjoy dancing to the music with some chick out there.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Hank Shocklee from the Bomb Squad, and, before that, Spectrum City [soundsystem], says there was some jam at college and all the MCs were terrible, and then you got on the mic to make some announcement, and he went, âThatâs the guy.â

Chuck D

Back in the day it wasnât about your rhymes. You had to sound good because most systems were inferior. I would be, âOne, two, one, two.â Then someone else would come on, â[Weak voice] One, two, one, two.â âYou ainât cutting it, sit your ass down.â When I get on the mic I know no oneâs going to be louder, and all I have to do is be clear, and put some words together. Everyone else is sitting down because theyâre not loud and clear and rocking the music like that. Later on, when people talked about flows, youâre talking about enhanced systems, studios which balance out the soundâ¦ but, when it comes down to it, youâve either got the pipes or you havenât. People who sing in front of a hall, youâll say, âWow, theyâre really cutting through.â Someone who sounded great in the studio might not sound great live because some people need help and some donât. Melle Mel was the first MC to blow me away because he didnât need a mic. [Puts mic down], Youâd hear him clear and be like, âDamn.â But the next person would need the mic and amps and heâs complaining to the sound person, âTurn me up, turn me up!â Then Melle Mel would grab it and be like: âONE, TWO, ONE, TWO.â I heard that. So the whole thing about microphone kings, masters of ceremony, was that the MC had to cut through because systems were wack, and if they were scratchy and you already had the DJ in the back [makes beat with mouth], âONE, TWO, ONE, TWO!â â thatâs gonna grab your attention. Thatâs why when we talk about up-to-date things... Today when we talk about MCs in a whole different way, weâre talking about studio-enhanced to bring all the nuances out. I remember one time someone told me a story about the blues, a harmonica guy Sonny Boy Williamsonâ¦ He was over in the UK and they were asking him, âWhat do you do to get the microphone that way? Whatâs the technique?â Theyâre checking out engineers and that technical bullshit. Sonny said, âItâs right here [gestures to mouth].â Some things you have, some things you donât.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

What finally gave you the confidence to make records?

Chuck D

It wasnât a confidence thing, it was something that was worth my time. I loved doing the radio, and I still love doing the radio. You donât have to be seen, just heard, you can be behind the scenes. We made our first record, âCheck Out the Radio,â so we could sell our shows. I was a big fan of Mr. Magic, Afrika Islam, the Zulu Beats and the Worldâs Famous Supreme Team.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

These are all pioneering radio DJs in New York City.

Chuck D

I know weâre talking about a load of stuff before you were born, way back, but itâs very important. If you say you love the music, youâve got to pick up on some of the reasons why some of this started in order to be able to innovate and take it to 2012 and 2010. And also at Red Bull Music Academy, you want to separate yourself from someone else who does what youâre doing, just because they like it. Separate yourself from someone who might say, âI do that shit that you do, I donât need no school.â All this is important, and since I was there and I was able to retain that surrounding, then itâs important that I spread it. What good is an old head like me, if I canât drop some jewels for you to pick up and use yourself?

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Radio was important because it was also the foundation of being part of a community, something beyond music.

Chuck D

Thatâs correct, because we talked directly to our community and they were able to see us. That was a beautiful thing about radio back in the days of R&B, by which I mean Reagan and Bush. So, we talked directly to the people in the laundromats and bus stops, and that was very important. When people ask me about rap music today, I tell them the rappers do a load of things, the producers do a load of things, but the radio is terrible. Itâs never been worse â they give you nothing, they give you no information and they donât innovate, no sense of history. What they think is good, they only judge themselves, not by a higher order. The people who are supposed to bring it to the public, theyâre no good. Not the rappers, not the producers â although even some of the producers need to know more, because itâs not just about taking the sound, itâs about knowing the dynamics behind and the mentality of why it was created in the first place.

DJ â [to participant] whatâs your name again? [response inaudible] â he was finding a Mobb Deep sample on the Stylistics album from about 35 years ago. Before you even get into saying Mobb Deep took this sample, you have to get into the dynamics of the musicians that made it [in the first place]. Thom Bell was part of the Gamble & Huff team, so he would orchestrate The Stylistics and The Spinners, and so his use of horns and strings was immaculate, he was a perfectionist. His grooves from the Philadelphia Orchestra that Gamble & Huff also used, all of this is part of the science of why the music was made the way it was in the first place, which led me to think itâs groove is funky and itâs made to extend into a sample or even manipulate. Youâve got to go into the mind of the musician or the goal of what they would try to do. The Stylistics were there to hold you, make you swoon, so you think, âThis is a love ,â but itâs also there to get you on the floor to sway a certain way or to relate a certain way. That movement is still there in the musiciansâ mind and their chops. Itâs not just about, âIâm gonna snatch a sound and make it the way I want it to make it.â Thatâs half the answer. But the other half is saying, âWhy was it created in the first place?â

Thatâs why they call people like Afrika Bambaataa âThe Master of Recordsâ; Grand Mixer DXT, a master of records; Questlove from The Roots, a master of records. Not just to understand the record but the musicians and the engineers who made the recordings. You canât get into the science of some of that hot Atlantic Pretty Purdie, James Gadson beats, without understanding Tom Dowd as an engineer, and not just whether he engineered that record or not, but his influence on that sound and other engineers. Or the influence of James Brown or Clyde Stubblefield. Whatâs the engineering technique, what are the David Matthewsâ arrangements, which led to the James Brown funk section, but his arrangements on top of Fred Wesleyâs.

Youâve got to be able to understand this to be able to say, âWeâre going to make some more incredible music for 2012, or incredible mixtapes, or whatever.â And I just donât think the radio stations and jocks, they donât have it in them to take it to the next phase, no Isley Brothers pun intended.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Well, you speak about arrangements and production. What motivated you and Hank and Public Enemy to make the sounds you made, which were very distinct and pretty much unprecedented?

Chuck D

We didnât make the sounds, we wanted to be able to make a new arrangement of the sounds. Because we had a knowledge of the records and we had a respect for the records and the different genres, our thing was trying to make it all work. We didnât know where R&B was in the mid-â80s. We thought the worst thing that ever happened to it was the use of synthesizers, or rather that synthesizers started to use the musician. Stevie Wonder would pimp the hell out of a synthesizer, but synthesizers and drum machines started to use the producer. So, you would have this corny-ass [makes beat with mouth] that we wanted to rebel against. Our whole goal was, âWeâre going to destroy the music businessâs concept of music with music.â We wanted to eradicate every bit of smooth R&B that was made off the face of the earth, also English pop. Most of the music made from 1979 to 1986, except for rap records and a lot of organic types of music, most music was terrible, just wack. Our goal was to wipe that shit off the face of the musical map, that was Public Enemyâs goal as sonic assassins.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

By the same token, when Public Enemy came out, there was resistance from within hip-hop as well. Maybe this is a myth, but you guys performed at Latin Quarter and reputedly Melle Mel and others heckled you.

Chuck D

Melle Mel heckled us because he thought we were part of the contingent that dissed Mr Magic.
